{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3731744,"name":"Logan de Laar","username":"Logandelaar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/logandelaar/{size}/270464_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-05T13:15:51.760Z","cooked":"

So I have been working on my bot over the past couple of weeks and in the process, 3 of our Kraken X60s power terminals have broken out of the motor. I am at school right now and don’t have a picture, but will add one later today. It looks like these terminals are glued in, but I wanted to see if other teams have run into this issue and how they solved it. Before anyone mentions over torquing the bolts, I was using the torque wrench and wasn’t anywhere near the needed torque. Anyone else run into the same issue, and how did you solve it?

Using too long of a screw will pop them out. CTRE can repair them for a fee.

I was using the provided screws with the provided 10 gauge pre crimped wires

We did this to a Kraken. For us, the issue was using the longer screws provided with the Anderson adapter after making the decision to stop using the adapter. Not sure if this applies to you, but mentioning it here in case others experience the same.

For information:

They are not mechanically glued in - rather soldered, and to a hefty copper power plane which is going to take ALOT of heat to repair.

Its something skilled technicians with the right equipment may be able to repair, but anything shy of that like DIY will always be suspect. Simply gluing them back in place will result in a still non-functional motor.

I would follow @daltzsmith advice and reach out to CTRE for warranty evaluation and repair options. Their repair is going to be orders of magnitude more trustworthy, they may even simply replace the motor controller completely as it may be more cost efficient than re-soldering the ring terminal lands to the existing PCB.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-09-05T15:10:26.450Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":158,"readers_count":157,"score":81.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505997,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-power-terminals-falling-out","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-power-terminals-falling-out/505997/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3731958,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-05T18:15:00.169Z","cooked":"

We had something like this happen once (I suspect) as the result of being a bit too rough on the motor and accidentally hitting/pulling it on the cables or something (thus exerting force on the lugs). The Krakens are pretty well built but the lugs are definitely susceptible to sheer/impact forces moreso than other motors with soldered-in wires. Still, we like the flexibility of the cable lugs, we’ve just learned you have to be careful with them, the PCBs they’re soldered on to are a bit fragile.

If CTRE/WCP was looking for a good upgrade for Krakens (a v1.1 or something), it would definitely be nice if it was possible to secure the lugs to the housing instead of just the PCB (though I imagine that’s difficult without creating all kinds of shorting issues).

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-09-05T18:17:59.944Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":94,"readers_count":93,"score":28.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505997,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-power-terminals-falling-out","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-power-terminals-falling-out/505997/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3731960,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-05T18:22:11.852Z","cooked":"

The normal soldering irons, hobby grade and professional, don’t put out sufficient heat energy** to get the area of the joint to a high enough temperature to melt the solder. They can get that area of the board hot enough to soften the resins in the board material so that it delaminates, causing irreparable damage.

** There is a difference between heat energy contained within the tip of the iron and the temperature of the tip of the iron. It typically requires an iron with a pretty massive tip to contain sufficient heat energy for jobs like this.
